narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: We're really going to miss Erin Mansur.
Too fast and there is way too much material for just a couple weeks of instruction. This course should be taught for a full semester.

I really enjoyed the class, but it would be better if there was more time. If it were possible to teach the class over an entire semester, that would be better.In general, very useful for a student interested in energy planning.
This is one of the best classes I have taken in my 6 years at Yale. I have probably never taken a class that was designed so thoughtfully to maximize learning and comprehension.
na

Q10: great introduction to energy markets!Q4: Group assignments take a lot of time, but are worth it. This course is good to take during the 1st half of the semester, but would have been too much work in the second half.
Be ready to use a lot of Economics terms/concepts. If you haven't taken any Economics, consider taking that before taking this class.
Course material, OPEC and electricity games played
Learning the economic concepts was very useful and I enjoyed the "game" exercises, which helped to learn how to apply the concepts in practice.

The professor was and incredibly articulate and interesting lecturer. He did and excellent job of giving us condensed but still thorough information on every relevant part of energy markets. This course was great for breadth and depth. Also, the two strategy games were a really amazing way to learn and apply the concepts- this is the class experience that I will talk about when I leave here.
OPEC Strategy Game and Electricity Game ( very helpful to in understanding concepts).
Mansur made the class good by being accessible and a decent speaker/presenter. The subject matter is interesting as well.
the theoretical framework used.
professorlecturesgames

The class games were insightful the business process of designing and anticipating changes in energy markets. Erin Manseur was an enthusiastic and excellent teacher, readily helpful outside of class to respond to my questions.
The readings.The structure of the areas covered.The games.
The issues covered were very enlightening.
Prof. Mansur class design, flow and knowledge of topics. He rocks!

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More energy classes
See above - the timing is tough. It could be a full semester course.
I think the reading material were not too much related to specific.

The energy strategy games involved too much late-night work. Assignments were do at midnight and if you weren't awake at midnight you might not see if the other teams changed their bids. At a minimum, move this time up to 10pm.The electricity game was too confusing and complicated. Simplify it and people will internalize the information more.
better application to contemporary issues in the energy industry.
no improvements
I would have liked a small intro class on financial modeling in excel. I often had to rely on others' expertise to figure out bidding strategies.
I would reduce the time spent on the gasoline market and spend more time on more interesting areas such as renewables.

This course could have included discussions on the environmental impacts of the structure of energy markets. The incentives and disincentives in the market for environmental improvement could have been discussed. The renewables section was a bit rushed. Not enough environmental focus to be a FES cross-listed course.
Provide some type of preparation of put material available to students not familiar on Economic topics

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Help from the instructor was great. I received no responses from the TA on several questions during the course.
Overall, good. Prof. Mansur was very good about meeting with students.

Both were very accessible, responsive, and helpful. The TA met with me independently to help me get up to speed on some concepts, and the Professor met with a group of students including myself to help us prepare for the test. Both were especially responsive to those of us that came into the class without as much modeling experience which was really helpful.
Well, TA job was just to facilitate in communication. TA wasn't helpful in technical knowledge. However, Prof Mansoor was available to help students.
Good. Erin and JF were very accessible.
totally available.
great
Both the TA and the professor were extremely responsive and helpful outside of class.
Awesome.
I didnt request much help.
Good

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It was one of the few energy related courses offered to FES students. I hope that it will continue to be taught, even though Erin Mansur is leaving.
Yes we dont have enough energy classes, and this was great.
I'm interested in energy, so it fits nicely.
I am interested in energy law and policy - this was good background.
This is an excellent course for anyone interested in working with or in energy markets or policy. It is really a loss to the school that this will not be offered in future years.

I am also interested in Energy issues and how energy markets currently operates and where Renewable energy can fit-in in future. so understanding of energy markets is definitely helpful in energy related careers.
Yes. Thanks for offering it. It's sad to see Erin go but I hope SOM/FES offer it in the future.
very much related to environmental finance.
energy economics
As a forestry student, the business perspective I gained from this class was invaluable. I think more forestry students should take SOM courses.
Straight at the core of my interest in energy.
Good undertanding of Ebergy Markets. A must for students interested in Energy

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It's one of the few energy focused courses available.
Very interested in energy
To learn about the functioning of energy markets.
I needed more background on the economic side of energy management - my background is in policy.
To understand Energy Markets and its operations.
good subject matter
to learn more about energy economics.
interest in energy
To gain business perspectives on energy systems planning.
Straight at the core of my interest in energy.
To learn better the current and possible future incentives in the energy markets markets for environmental protection.
I was interested in Energy and wanted to get as much energy courses as possible.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes. Most students were 2nd year SOM students, and I learned a lot from their approaches to issues.
Yes it was actually more than expected. There is enough material in this class to extend it into a full semester
Yes
Yes! A lot of good information, oriented towards practice.
It far surpassed my expectations
I think, the course was nicely designed especially due to its in group work on OPEC and Electricity games. it was a good learning experience in energy issues.
yes
yes
yes
It went beyond my expectations. This was an extremely stimulating, engaging and well-thought out class.
It exceeded my expectations.
No. But it was great in other ways.
Exceeded!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, very well structured course
Yes
Much more
I think I did and was helpful to the extent I could understand relevant policies. however, being FES student, it was a little difficult to grasp the basics of energy policies and marketing strategy.
yes
yes
yes
More than I expected.
Yes.
No. But it was great in other ways.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantage: learn about SOM styledisadvantage: need excel-people to be good at the group projects.
Good mix of people, the assignments were fun
Some students free ride on the work of others. On the other hand, some students bring additional skills and knowledge lacking by others.

In this case it was good because it was more realistic - more like actually creating business strategies with the concepts we learned - and I was able to learn from students with a better economic/business backgrounds.It's difficult to arrange times to meet, and organize paper-writing.

This is one of the few instances at Yale where I have appreciated the group component. It was set up well for group members to learn from one another and I really enjoyed playing these games with teams.
It was very helpful.
It was nice that the working group was assigned so we could work with different types of students. The working groups worked out well.
learn from eachother. no disadvantages.
disadvantage - some people free-ride in group projects
Overall, I enjoyed the group work and the friendly competition between groups in class. Some group members were lazier than others, which was expected I suppose.
Only advantages. We learned from each other.
Amazing experience. It was a good example of complementing skills and teamwork.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Remember its a short course, so get as much out of it as you can.
Have a background in economics. It is a struggle if you do not have the basic concepts down before starting.
This course is certainly necessary for students who are looking into Energy and Environment portfolio.
take it
great primer on energy markets and economics
It helps to have experience using excel programs to execute specific modeling tasks.
Make sure you are interested in and know a little bit of economicsbefore jumping into this course.
Be ready for some hard-core microeconomics and game theory.
